Package algorithms.misc

Class MiscMath0

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.misc.MiscMath0
  • public class MiscMath0
extends java.lang.Object
    miscellaneous math methods. some could probably be improved. first implemented in projects https://github.com/nking/two-point-correlation w/ Copyright (c) 2013-2015 Nichole King http://nking.github.io/two-point-correlation/ using The MIT License (MIT) and https://github.com/nking/curvature-scale-space-corners-and-transformations w/ Copyright (c) 2014 Climb With Your Feet and using The MIT License (MIT) then moved to this shared library project which has the same copyright and license.
    Author:
    nichole

      • roundUpByLargestPower

        public static float roundUpByLargestPower​(float f)
        Round number up to the next digit in the largest power. MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(31.1f) == 40.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(0.11f) == 1.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(-0.011f) == -0.02f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(310.1f) == 400.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(-3.1) == -4.0f; MiscMath0.roundUpByLargestPower(3.1) == 4.0f;
        Parameters:
        f -
        Returns:

      • roundDownByLargestPower

        public static float roundDownByLargestPower​(float f)
        Round number down to in the largest power. For example, roundDownByLargestPower(3.1) returns 3.0 roundDownByLargestPower(-3.1) returns -4.0 roundDownByLargestPower(31.1) returns 30.0
        Parameters:
        f -
        Returns:

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> findStrongPeakIndexes​(HistogramHolder h,
                                                                      float frac)
        for the given histogram, returns the indexes of the primary peak and any peaks which are larger than frac*maxPeak above their neighboring values.
        Parameters:
        h -
        frac - the fraction of the y value of the maximum peak that is used as a critical limit that any other peaks must have in excess of their neighboring points. For example, 0.1.
        Returns:

      • calculateQuartiles

        public static double[] calculateQuartiles​(double[] x)
        calculate the quartiles Q1, Q2, and Q3 of x as 
         x = ascending sort(x)
 n = x.length;
 Q1 = median of x[0] through x[n/2] which is x[n/4];
 Q2 = median of x = x[n/2];
 Q3 = median of x[n/2] through x[n-1] = x[(int)0.75*n];
        The IQR is Q3 - Q1;
        Parameters:
        x -
        Returns:
        an array holding Q1, Q2, Q3, min and max

      • findInliersUsingTukeyFences

        public static int[] findInliersUsingTukeyFences​(double[] x)
        uses Tukey fences to find inlier indexes in x with factor k=1.5 
            calculated as
       q = calculateQuartiles(x);
       iqr = q[2]-q[0];
       inliers are in the range [q[0] - k*iqr, q[2] + k*iqr], inclusive.
        Parameters:
        x -
        Returns:

      • findFarInliersUsingTukeyFences

        public static int[] findFarInliersUsingTukeyFences​(double[] x)
        uses Tukey fences to find inlier indexes in x with factor k=3 
            calculated as
       q = calculateQuartiles(x);
       iqr = q[2]-q[0];
       inliers are in the range [q[0] - k*iqr, q[2] + k*iqr], inclusive.
        Parameters:
        x -
        Returns:

      • findInliersUsingTukeyFences

        public static int[] findInliersUsingTukeyFences​(double[] x,
                                                double k)
        uses Tukey fences to find inlier indexes in x. 
            calculated as
       q = calculateQuartiles(x);
       iqr = q[2]-q[0];
       inliers are in the range [q[0] - k*iqr, q[2] + k*iqr], inclusive.
        Parameters:
        x -
        k -
        Returns:

      • calculateMedianOfAbsoluteDeviation

        public static double[] calculateMedianOfAbsoluteDeviation​(double[] x)
        calculate the median of absolute deviation (MAD) as 
          absDev_i = abs(x_i - median(x))
        mad = median( absDev)
        and returns the median, followed by the median of absolute deviation. to use the MAD as one uses standard deviation in determining outliers, use stDev = k*MAD where k is a constant scale factor. For gaussian k~1.4826. Then and outlier is outside the range [median - 3*MAD, median + 3*MAD].
        Parameters:
        x -
        Returns:
        an array holding the median of absolute deviation of x, the median, the min, and the max.

      • numberOfSetBits

        public static int numberOfSetBits​(long x)
        determine the number of set bits. this method uses the hamming weight which uses binary magic numbers. 
             reference:
     https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_weight
     method popcount64c
        Parameters:
        x - the bitstring with the set bits to count
        Returns:
        the number of bits set in x

      • logspace

        public static gnu.trove.list.array.TDoubleArrayList logspace​(float start,
                                                             float stop,
                                                             int num,
                                                             boolean endpoint)
        method from scipy's numpy package to return numbers spaced evenly on a log scale. 
             numpy is licensed under BSD 3-clause "New" or "Revised" License
      
     https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
        Parameters:
        start - is the starting value of the sequence.
        stop - float is the final value of the sequence, unless `endpoint` is False. In that case, ``num + 1`` values are spaced over the interval in log-space, of which all but the last (a sequence of length ``num``) are returned.
        num - : Number of samples to generate. Default is 50.
        endpoint - : If true, `stop` is the last sample. Otherwise, it is not included. Default is True.

      • linspace

        public static gnu.trove.list.array.TFloatArrayList linspace​(float start,
                                                            float stop,
                                                            int num,
                                                            boolean endpoint)
        adapted method from scipy's numpy package to return evenly spaced numbers over a specified interval 
             numpy is licensed under BSD 3-clause "New" or "Revised" License
      
     https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
        Parameters:
        start - is the starting value of the sequence.
        stop - float is the final value of the sequence, unless `endpoint` is False. In that case, ``num + 1`` values are spaced over the interval in log-space, of which all but the last (a sequence of length ``num``) are returned.
        num - : Number of samples to generate. Default is 50.
        endpoint - : If true, `stop` is the last sample. Otherwise, it is not included. Default is True.

      • mean

        public static double[] mean​(double[] data,
                            int nDimensions)
        calculates the mean of the data per dimension and returns it as a point in all dimensions.
        Parameters:

        nDimensions - the number of dimensions of a point
        Returns:
        an array holding the mean per dimension, e.g. point_0_0, point_0_1, point_0_2...point_0_{nDimensions-1}]

      • computeNDivKTimesNMinusK

        public static long computeNDivKTimesNMinusK​(int n,
                                            int k)
        compute n!/k!(n-k)!. Note that if n or k are larger than 12, computeNDivKTimesNMinusKBigIntegerExact is used and in that case, if the result is larger than Long.MAX_VALUE an exception is thrown. (Aho & Ullman "Foundations of Computer Science")
        Parameters:
        n -
        k -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - thrown when result is out of range of type long

      • computeNDivNMinusK

                                      int k)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • writeToBigEndianBytes

        public static byte[] writeToBigEndianBytes​(long value)
        write value to a byte array in big endian, that is LSB in highest order bit (MSB is in lowest memory address). these are signed values stored as twos complement and can be input to BigInteger's constructor.
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:

      • calcSampleSkewness

        public static double calcSampleSkewness​(double[] data)
        third standardized moment of skewness as sample skewness: 
          https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skewness
     g1 = kappa_3/((kappa_2)^(3/2))
        = (1/n) * summation from i=1 to n ( (x_i - mean)^3)
           / ([ (1/n) * summation from i=1 to n ( (x_i - mean)^2) ]^(3/2) )

           where kappa_2 is the 2nd cumulant = variance.
          kappa_3 = central moment which is skewness
        Parameters:
        data -
        Returns:

      • eulerMascheroniConstant

        public static double eulerMascheroniConstant()
        return the Euler-Mascheroni constant. It is the first derivative of the gamma function w.r.t. n at n=1. 
             Chap 19 of "Statistical Distributions" by Evans et al.
        Returns:
